replies.text:
@leonfrancis3418 Well, for one, we are trying to stay on topic and discuss the issue that arose in the video: a black man who is fine with creating more broken homes rather than facing and overcoming his fears around marriage. Behaviour that many black men engage in.

Having a "both sides" discussion regarding the creation of broken homes would have little merit given that black women almost always remain with the children and become their primary caregivers. They are not the absent parent in this equation.

If your argument is that they should not have had the children in the first place, then you, sir, are advocating for widescale celibacy until marriage (which black men DON'T want & have NEVER supported) and/or widescale abortion (which is extremely dangerous for women).

Let's not forget that most single black mothers did not intentionally set out to create broken homes. They had children by men with whom they were in a relationship and who they believed would be there for them and the children. An error on their part, yes, but in no way is it equivalent to the behaviour of black men like Cam. text: The point about the social-emotional aspect that FD brought up is incredibly relevant as he stated it is both relevant and irrelevant. There's no real intention of Newton building a "home." As Dr. Bryant also emphasized, children from these situations may grow up with deficits due to an emotionally ineffective father. This is a powerful conversation you're all having about fatherhood and the different ways families can be built, but what's crucial to highlight here is that Cam Newton's actions reflect irresponsibility, even though he may believe he's "taking his time." The consequences for the children involved are real and long-lasting.

@Earthakitty how is the nuclear family not working? And who is it not working for and why? And since we grew up in america how are we going to convince our family and friends to live with us when thats not the norm in our country?
I understand wanting help with your children, but do most people without kids want to help raise other peoples kids? No they don‚Äôt. 

Nothing in me wants to leave the house i have with my husband to move in with my aunt and help raise my little cousin üòÇ i can babysit here and there but thats all. and id venture to say most financially stable people do not want to either
Now this notion of communal living and helping to raise other peoples kids might work if the following conditions apply:
1. You and your family live in poverty and staying together in one household would benefit them and you with stability because without the financial support of each other, it would be hard to make it
2. You have a widowed or single parent or relative that is lonely anyway and wants to help with child rearing
3. The people helping you raise your kids also have kids and you are helping to raise their kids as well

But outside of that, people who are not in those specific situations and were raised in US are not interested in selling their homes to live in a communal setting where they raise your kids with you. It has to be a mutually beneficial setup

author: @ookamiblade6318
text: I knew my family was weird, the only dude who had multiple wives and secrets that didn't come out until the funeral was my Russian Jewish Great Uncle who passed for White (he was alive during the red scare so Russian Jew wasn't quite white yet and we know this because he married my Great Aunt before Loving vs Virginia) the secret that came out at the funeral is he forgot to obtain the signature of the second wife on the divorce papers before marrying my great AuntüòÖ. He was military so survivorship benefits were a mess to figure out. All the Black dudes in my family (barring the one who died early before kids in a freak accident) were loyal and present husbands and fathers. My grandpa was Chinese and also died very young and his best friend took over the family as a father figure after his passing, but he ran into some immigation woes so he was absent for a time before they managed a marriage to bring him back into the country‚Ä¶ so my Asian step grandpa was the closest to an absentee father in my family for a hot minute. All this to say race likely has less of an impact on these things than the narratives would have you believe.

author: @LamarFrancis
text:
Last comment lol: 

I think an evergreen point that was hit somewhat directly and somewhat indirectly is the importance of being open to reimagining the ways we speak about these topics, but the importance in NOT compromising the truth.

Often times they‚Äôre calls to rebrand a message to make it more palatable and effective, & that‚Äôs fine. And often can be necessary in situations. Rhetorical skill is an ever evolving journey. 

However, I think it‚Äôs often mixed with a call to change the message, which not only ends up losing the core that was built, but also moves away from the actual goal.

It reminds me of how pundits talk about political strategy. Sure, it‚Äôs important to try to make your policy and your message appealing to new/other people, in order to win a race and do the good you want. But if you‚Äôre changing the good message and changing the good policy as a whole, now you‚Äôre just winning to win. That‚Äôs when it becomes less about community and more about self. 

The point of capitalism lol.

author: @coreybass3231
text:
55:32

In order to create an "archy", you do need coercion.  You also need a group of people who believe in what you believe that will coerce the others into that framework.  No kingdom was built by one person, and no systemic structures was built by a sole individual.  And that's where the rest of his spiel goes wrong because it relies on hyper-individualism and exceptionalism as though society was built by individuals with no input from group dynamics other than addressing the individual at the head of the group.

And then it just turns into "who am I to judge."  And...if you have no judgement, then you have no opinion or ability to actually work within the group to figure out how live together as a functioning whole.

It's smart-dumb babble designed to disengage without being questioned on the "why" because the answer falls into hyper-individuality and "who am I to judge."  Because it uses the "exceptional" to justify doing nothing.

Just because one methhead can perform his task competently does not mean that you want 4 other methheads doing the same tasks or any tasks.  Because meth does not work like that for the group.  Just like just because the "nuclear family" worked for one family does not mean that 4 families weren't fucked up for it. Because the nuclear family was created as an excuse to buy products and services and outwardly look "healthy" to anyone outside of the herd rather than an idea that centers around fostering a functional, healthy family dynamic within the herd.

Then again, Malcolm laid out who he was in the first moment he opened his mouth.  He has no real opinion, just information that keeps him safely unengaged.


The situations that Cam Newton and Nick Cannon are in is extraordinary.  Not because they have multiple kids out of wedlock, but because they are rich and successful Black men in an environment where 
a) they are expected to perform in a certain, almost minstrel -ly way because they are Black men
b) they are surrounded by "enablers" and "predators" because of their fame and wealth
c) they cannot extract themselves from that situation without risking losing that fame and wealth to support themselves and their kids and/or baby mommas.
d) they are aware of how fucked the situation is (on varying levels) but can't or won't do a thing about it because they risk losing the money and fame.

I'm not saying that what they're doing is right, because it isn't and that kind of environment is going to have a negative impact on those kids. But I think that in their heads, they're making the best of a bad situation with the options they have that allows them to keep the money and fame.  Which is selfish and toxic.

And people are talking about it because the minstrel show that Black people are forced to perform must always play out, no matter the economic circumstances.

author: @biabia9181
text:
‚ÄúOh this is an extraordinary situation that doesn‚Äôt need a bigger conversation about it‚Äù isn‚Äôt the right thing to say when ppl mention the inactivity of fathers in the black community. We ALL know men who do not take care of their children. We ALL do. This isn‚Äôt some shooting star situation. This is regular circumstance we all see and most experience everyday. It‚Äôs more extraordinary to see a father with 1 baby mother in one home with all his children. You‚Äôre not being as effective of a father as you can be if you do not live with your children.

Just replace ‚Äúfather‚Äù with ‚Äúmother‚Äù. Is a mother more effective when she lives with her children or when she doesn‚Äôt? Y‚Äôall understand it when it comes to a mother role but totally miss the point when it comes to the father role. And again, we have differing opinions on father roles. A lot of father role opinions are misconstrued.

Father isn‚Äôt just ‚Äúgo to work, play with kids, pay bills, and go to sleep‚Äù. Father is leadership, counseling, mentoring, fixing, understanding, comforting, loving, cherishing, teaching, nurturing, healing, etc. it‚Äôs WAY more than ppl think because why? Ppl are so used to fathers not being in the home so literally JUST being in the home is seen as a big deal. 

Let‚Äôs raise the bar folks. And the first step in problem solving is acknowledging the problem. If we don‚Äôt acknowledge the problem, we can‚Äôt expect change.

text: I am not saying the nuclear family is ideal HOWEVER as someone who was a product of divorce (which yes is different then what Can is doing) I really resonated with the idea that Cam is creating houses and will potentially in the future have a home. replies.text:
I'm in your shoes, and I don't think I have resentment. But my father was certainly not a good father to me, so all I have is hope that he can be better to them than he was to us.

And frankly, he wasn't good when they were married and together. I don't think him staying would have improved his behavior. 

I do agree that a guy with 8 kids in 8 places just isn't gonna have the time to do anything with them. There's only so many minutes in a day. But I think there are many ways one can fail as a parent that have nothing to do with marriage or remarriage or how many kids
